Description.val:
This line item funds modifications to avionics equipment used for Fleet Opposing Forces and Adversary Air Electronic Warfare training exercises.  The overall goal is to accurately simulate the known and postulated electronic warfare characteristics and tactics of various radar and jammer threats for fleet training.  Operational, Safety, and Improvement Program (OSIP) 119-83 Fleet Electronic Warfare Support Group equipment, AN/ALQ-167 (jammer) and AN/AST-6 (radar simulator) had been installed and/or carried aboard the EA-6B, F-4, F-14, EP-3J, EC-24A and KC-135 aircraft, prior to deactivation of the associated training missions for these aircraft.

Current equipment, AN/ALQ-167, AST-6 and follow-on AN/AST-9 pod variants are carried aboard F/A-18, Lear Jet, Kfir (F-21), Hawker/Hunter (F-58), Gulfstream (G-1), and F-16 aircraft.  Internal aircraft installation variants, AN/ULQ-21/24 are used in targets and the AN/ALQ-237 rack installation is used on F-5N.  The remaining quantity of 20 legacy AST-6 pods are no longer repairable.  These pods are being augmented/replaced by AN/AST-9 and will be flown until the end of their operational service life.  FY10-FY12 and prior years' Below Threshold Reprogramming (BTR)funding procured 34 Advanced Digital Radio Frequency Memory (DRFM) systems to address Adversary Forces training requirements per Naval Strike Air Warfare Center Urgent Operational Need Statement.  The Adversary systems (AKA HAVE ALL-Filthy Badger) comprised 19 ALQ-167 pods, 12 F-5N rack installs and 3 ACaP pods procured in coordination with the United States Air Force (USAF).  The remaining pod inventory, as of Oct 2012, of legacy ALQ-167 pods is 33 with a goal of converting one pod per year to DRFM configuration starting in FY 13.

Adversary Electronic Attack (EA) DRFM program systems completed deliveries in FY13 as funded under the Abbreviated Acquisition Plan (AAP) in FY10-12. As a result, all future installations are modifications to Fleet systems based on the EA DRFM Roadmap for Filthy Badger classified program requirements. DON15 shifts program focus from full production  to the Filthy Badger modification schedule and support of the required engineering and logistics to accomplish these upgrades in future years,reducing unit cost.

Name.@footnote: Adversary Electronic Attack(EA) DRFM program systems completed deliveries in FY13 as funded under the Abbreviated Acquisition Plan (AAP) in FY10-12. As a result, all future installations are modifications to Fleet systems based on the EA DRFM Roadmap for Filthy Badger classified program requirements. DON15 shifts program focus from full production to the Filthy Badger modification schedule and support of the required engineering and logistics to accomplish these annual updates in future years reducing the unit cost.  There are two reasons Cost element 3.3, ILS, is increased. First, this program is a non-standard program that support Fleet Training supplying Adversary Forces with EA systems in a Counter Air role flown on military aircraft and also supplying Opposing Forces with EA systems for Surface Training. Neither of these programs are under an Aviation Depot Level Repair (AVDLR) support posture and all of the aircraft are unique configurations. The logistics and engineering requirements are wide spread even though we are making minor modifications (1 mod per year). Second - Opposing Forces ALQ-167 variants and AST-9 variants are aging rapidly and that puts a significant Logistics and engineering burden on support of these systems.There are a number of ALQ-167 Pod variants.

FY 10 - 13 funding procured 34 AN/ALQ-167 DRFM pod variants to address Adversary Air requirements per Naval Strike Air Warfare Center Urgent Operational Need Statement.  3. Adversary Electronic Attack (EA) DRFM program systems completed deliveries in FY13 as funded under the Abbreviated Acquisition Plan (AAP) for FY10-13. As a result, all future installations are modifications to Fleet systems based on the EA DRFM Roadmap for Filthy Badger classified program requirements. DON15 shifts program focus from full production to the Filthy Badger modification schedule and support of the required engineering and logistics to accomplish these annual updates in future years reducing the unit cost.

Cost increases in FY14 and out because FEWSG is a non-standard program that supports Fleet Training supplying Adversary Forces with EA systems in a Counter Air role flown on military aircraft and also supplying Opposing Forces with EA systems for Surface Training. Neither of these programs are under an Aviation Depot Level Repair (AVDLR) support posture and all of the aircraft are unique configurations. The logistics and engineering requirements are wide spread even though we are making minor modifications (1 mod per year). Opposing Forces ALQ-167 variants and AST-9 variants are aging rapidly and that puts a significant Logistics and engineering burden on support of these systems. There are a number of ALQ-167 Pod variants.  This variance requires unique modifications and hardware.

Description.val:
DESCRIPTION/JUSTIFICATION: The AN/ALQ-167 pods electronically simulate threat airborne radar jamming systems.  The AN/ALQ-167 pod components can also be installed internally in aircraft.  When these components are used in this type of configuration, they are nomenclatured AN/DLQ-3 and AN/ULQ-21/24. AN/AST-4 was replaced by AN/AST-6.  The AN/AST-6 pod electronically simulates several types of threat anti-ship missile seeker and air-to-air missile systems.  Original variants of these podded devices were first introduced into the fleet in 1980 and proved exceptionally useful in readiness exercises and for tactical contingencies.  Subsequent variants were developed to meet the technology advances of the threat systems.  The tactical contingency pods were removed from fleet service in FY2002 and returned to the pod depot for component reuse.  This program provides for the procurement and continued support of additional quantities of these pods or conversion of older pod variants and/or contingency pods to newer variants for use by Fleet Area Control and Surveillance Facility in support of operational fleet training and for Top Gun/Adversary Squadrons in support of adversary  air exercises.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES: The objective for the AN/ALQ-167 was 186 pods.  Prior to the tactical contingency pod divestiture, inventory was 146.  The AN/ALQ-167 pods avionics are being upgraded to provide increased performance/advanced capability using Digital Radio Frequency Memory (DRFM) technology.  Internal installations of the DRFM avionics planned for Adversary Squadron F-5 aircraft funded in  FY 10 -12 have been completed.  Remaining quantities are for pod carriage capability aboard F-18, F-16, Kfir, Hawker/Hunter and Gulfstream I aircraft.  Legacy pod inventory as of Oct 2012 is 33 with a goal of converting one pod per year to DRFM configuration.  There are 20 AN/AST-6 production assets.  AN/AST-6 was phased out of service and replaced by 30 AN/AST-9 production assets in FY 2011.  AN/ALE-43 pods have been transitioned from fleet training use to tactical use.  No future AN/AST-6 or AN/ALE-43 pods or pod modifications are being funded via this Operational, Safety, and Improvement Program. 

Adversary Electronic Attack (EA) DRFM program systems completed deliveries in FY13 as funded under the Abbreviated Acquisition Plan (AAP) for FY10-13. As a result, all future installations are modifications to Fleet systems based on the EA DRFM Roadmap for Filthy Badger classified program requirements. DON15 shifts program focus to the Filthy Badger modification schedule and support of the required engineering and logistics to accomplish these upgrades in future years. Shifting from full production to the modification schedule reduces the unit cost to $51k and increase funding for engineering and logistics tasks associated with the modifications.
